title: Command of Evidence
subtitle: Finding & Using Textual Support
learning_objectives: Locate relevant evidence to support claims
Evaluate the strength of textual evidence
Connect evidence to central ideas and arguments
Practice with authentic SAT Command of Evidence questions

content.heading: Learning Objectives
content.text: In this lesson, you'll master finding and using textual evidence - a critical skill for supporting arguments and understanding author's claims.
bullet_points: Learn how to locate relevant evidence in passages
Understand different types of evidence (examples, data, quotes)
Practice connecting evidence to main ideas

content.heading: Understanding Textual Evidence
content.text: Command of Evidence questions ask you to identify which part of a passage best supports a given claim or conclusion.
main_points: Evidence = specific details, examples, or quotes that support a point
Must be directly stated in the passage (not implied)
Should clearly support the claim being made
Often includes data, statistics, expert opinions, or concrete examples

example.setup: If a passage argues 'Exercise improves mental health'
example.good_evidence: Studies show 30 minutes of daily exercise reduces anxiety by 25%
example.poor_evidence: Many people feel better after working out

content.reveal_text: The key is finding SPECIFIC, MEASURABLE support rather than general statements.

strategy_steps.description: Read the claim or conclusion carefully
Look for specific details that relate to the claim
Check that the evidence directly supports the point
Choose the most specific and relevant evidence

content.passage: Recent studies indicate that urban gardens significantly benefit local communities. Dr. Sarah Chen's research in Detroit found that neighborhoods with community gardens saw a 40% reduction in crime rates. Additionally, these gardens provide fresh produce to families, with 78% of participating households reporting improved nutrition. The social aspect is equally important, as residents form lasting friendships through shared gardening activities.
content.claim: Urban gardens provide multiple benefits to communities
evidence_options: Neighborhoods with community gardens saw a 40% reduction in crime rates
78% of participating households reported improved nutrition
Dr. Sarah Chen conducted research in Detroit
Residents form lasting friendships through shared activities

walkthrough.question: What is the main claim?
walkthrough.answer: Urban gardens provide multiple benefits to communities

walkthrough.question: Which evidence gives specific data about benefits?
walkthrough.answer: 40% reduction in crime rates and 78% improved nutrition

walkthrough.question: Why are these stronger than general statements?
walkthrough.answer: They provide measurable, specific data rather than vague claims

content.instructions: Read the passage and identify the best evidence for the given claim.
content.passage: Renewable energy adoption has accelerated dramatically in recent years. Solar panel costs have dropped 85% since 2010, making installation affordable for average homeowners. Wind energy now provides 8% of total US electricity generation, up from just 1% in 2000. Government incentives, including tax credits up to $7,500 for solar installations, have further encouraged adoption. Energy companies report that renewable sources now compete directly with fossil fuels on price.
content.claim: Economic factors are driving renewable energy adoption
content.question: Which sentence provides the strongest evidence for this claim?

options: Solar panel costs have dropped 85% since 2010
Wind energy now provides 8% of total US electricity
Government incentives include tax credits up to $7,500
Renewable sources now compete directly with fossil fuels on price
content.explanation: The 85% cost drop provides specific economic data showing how financial factors drive adoption.

content.heading: Comparing Evidence Strength
content.text: Not all evidence is equally strong. Learn to evaluate and rank evidence based on specificity and relevance.

evidence_ranking.weakest: General statements, personal anecdotes, unsupported claims

practice_scenarios.claim: Social media affects teen mental health
practice_scenarios.evidence_a: Many teens spend hours on social media daily
practice_scenarios.evidence_b: Studies link 3+ hours of daily social media use to 60% higher depression risk
practice_scenarios.better_choice: B - provides specific data and measurable correlation

content.heading: Command of Evidence Mastery
key_points: Strong evidence is specific and measurable
Look for data, statistics, and concrete examples
Evidence must directly support the given claim
Avoid general statements or unsupported opinions
content.strategy_reminder: Remember FIND: Focus on the claim, Identify relevant details, Note direct connections, Decide on the strongest evidence

practice_transition.text: Ready to apply your skills? Let's practice with real SAT questions that test your command of evidence!

content.message: Excellent! You've mastered the fundamentals of Command of Evidence.

slides.title: Quick Knowledge Check
slides.question: A passage claims 'Meditation reduces stress in students.' Which would be the STRONGEST evidence?
options: Students often feel calmer after meditating
Meditation has been practiced for thousands of years
A study of 200 students found 15-minute daily meditation reduced cortisol levels by 30%
Many teachers recommend meditation for stress relief
slides.explanation: Option C provides specific, measurable data (200 students, 15 minutes, 30% reduction) that directly supports the claim about stress reduction.

strategy_card.title: Command of Evidence Quick Reference
steps: 3. NOTE: Check direct connection to claim
tips: Look for numbers, percentages, research results
Evidence must be explicitly stated in passage

common_mistakes: Choosing general statements over specific data
Picking evidence that doesn't directly support the claim
